speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Welcome to the first episode of Open Minds, a podcast from Creative Commons.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: If you're new to Creative Commons, or CC as we call it, we're a nonprofit organization

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that works globally to build and sustain a thriving commons of shared knowledge and culture.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: to build and sustain a thriving commons of shared knowledge and culture.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: We work with partners all around the world to make information, creativity,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: research, and educational resources open and accessible to everyone without legal barriers.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: We're especially focused on sharing an openness that positively impact people in their communities.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It's CC's 20th anniversary this year, and to celebrate, we decided to launch this podcast,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: a series of conversations with people working on the issues we're involved with and excited about.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: That includes open culture, open education, open science, and open technology.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: We'll be bringing on folks with interesting ideas to share about sharing.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: My name's Eric Stoyer, I'm CC's creative director, and I'll be one of the voices you'll hear on this show.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: You'll also hear from several of my colleagues. We'll be sharing hosting and interview duties.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: For our debut episode, I talked to Catherine Styler, who is Creative Commons' CEO.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Catherine started at CC in 2020, after many years as a member of

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: the European Parliament for Scotland, and then more recently as the CEO of the Open Knowledge

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Foundation. It seemed like a good place to start for this podcast, hearing from CC's new leader

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: about her career and her vision for what's next for the Creative Commons movement.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I hope you enjoyed the conversation. And if you've got ideas for people we should be talking to on this show, send us a note.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Info at creativecommons.org.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And now, Catherine Styler.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Like all of us, you didn't start your career in this space because it's still a relatively new space.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So can we talk about where you did start your career?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Sure. So I started my career in politics. I don't think I ever thought I would ever be a politician, but in 1999, I was elected to serve Scotland in the European Parliament. And I held that position

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: for 20 years. Before that, I actually worked in the House of Commons for the first wheelchair

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: using member of the British Parliament, Dame Anne Begg, which was an incredible experience to work there too.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So politics was something that I never thought I would be elected to,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and therefore it was a bit of a surprise to some of my family and friends

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that I ended up being a politician for so long, Eric.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: From there, how did you get interested in the kinds of work

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that you've been doing for the last couple of years?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: In the European Parliament, I was vice chair of the Single Market Committee.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And in that capacity, I worked on digital policy and became what's called the rapporteur.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: That's just the MEP responsible for a piece of law.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And I was responsible for copyright.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And it was through that journey in

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: copyright that I became familiar with Creative Commons, but also could see the unfairness,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: the inequity, the power dynamics. And I wanted to have reformed copyright rules at the European

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Union level and fought very hard for those. Sadly, on many levels, we

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: didn't achieve that. And that was a lesson learned. I also was involved in the book Famine Work,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: which was led by the European Blind Union and other organisations fighting for visually,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: for blind and visually impaired people. And that got me interested in e-books.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And so I actually ran a campaign called the Open Knowledge Campaign, which little did I know that that would be what I'd be

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: working in seven, eight years later when I was working in that. And it got me interested in

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: issues around inequity, access to knowledge, and the unfairness that I could see, and the injustices that I could

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: see that were affecting individuals and communities. What did that open knowledge

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: campaign, what did it consist of? Was it sort of an awareness campaign?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Yeah, so it was actually really interesting, because it came about from, as I say, the work

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I was doing to do with the book famine that was attached to the Marrakesh Treaty work

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that we were doing to try and make sure that people who were blind

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and visually impaired had access to the same books and knowledge

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that we took for granted.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And sadly, at that point, and there's still much to do in this space,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: there was huge challenges to overcome.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But then it got me interested about e-book lending in public libraries.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And for some reason in Scotland, one particular local authority was doing superbly well in terms of e-book lending.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And it wasn't the local authority. It was in a very, very poor area.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: in terms of e-book lending.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And it wasn't the local authority.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: It was in a very, very poor area.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Turned out the person that was the key librarian happened to be really interested in technology,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: was really averse with new ways of thinking,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and so really revolutionised the library system

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: in this particular local area.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: He actually was headhunted for another local area.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And it made me think, well, if they can do this

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and make sure people have access,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: then why is this not happening in other places? And it then became the situation where you start

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: to understand about how licenses are important, about decision making at local areas and who gets

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: access to what was not very equitable. And therefore, our campaign was to make sure that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: everyone in Scotland had the same e-book access across the country.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: It's still a campaign I was still very interested in.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But there was clearly politics attached to that.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But also the way that publishers had so much power over libraries.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And so it's my attachment to public libraries and the need that we support public libraries in our communities as places and spaces for people to access knowledge and culture, regardless of income, became even more important.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I live in Dunfermline, which is where Andrew Carnegie was born.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And in fact, we have the first Carnegie Library in Dunfermline.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Above every Carnegie Library are the words, let there be light, not just the light of knowledge,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: but the light of public spaces. And I think to this day, we still live with that legacy of the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: importance of libraries that Carnegie led with, but which we still benefit to today.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Were libraries a big part of your life growing up?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Yeah, my mum and dad were both teachers. and my grandmother had to go and work when she was

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: 14 because her father passed away and the family had very little money. And so

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: my gran was very much about, you know, the importance of education, the importance of

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: knowledge and, you know, and to really, really value learning.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And although my gran left school without qualifications and worked in a grocer's shop,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: she was one of the most literate people I've ever met.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: In fact, my husband, who is from California,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: met my grandmother and was talking to him

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and found out that he had, you know,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Salinas, she could quote John Steinbeck directly to my husband, who was quite shocked that this

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: granny in Eastgill Bride was able to quote texts from John Steinbeck that he couldn't even quote.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So it's important that we value culture and knowledge. And I had that from a very early age.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that was attached to Creative Commons

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and also the culture,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: the public-minded, public interest,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: openness that is Creative Commons.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I don't know of any other organisation,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I think, you know,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that some of them make cookies

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: after they've been in a training session

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: over a CC certificate

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: would create CC-branded cookies for the person that was the trainer.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And that's just a tiny aspect of the generosity, the giving that is part of this movement.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And it's such an honor and privilege to not just be part of this community now, but also to lead the community.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

chunks.text: Welcome to the first episode of Open Minds, a podcast from Creative Commons.
If you're new to Creative Commons, or CC as we call it, we're a nonprofit organization
that works globally to build and sustain a thriving commons of shared knowledge and culture.
to build and sustain a thriving commons of shared knowledge and culture.
We work with partners all around the world to make information, creativity,
research, and educational resources open and accessible to everyone without legal barriers.
We're especially focused on sharing an openness that positively impact people in their communities.
It's CC's 20th anniversary this year, and to celebrate, we decided to launch this podcast,
a series of conversations with people working on the issues we're involved with and excited about.
That includes open culture, open education, open science, and open technology.
We'll be bringing on folks with interesting ideas to share about sharing.
My name's Eric Stoyer, I'm CC's creative director, and I'll be one of the voices you'll hear on this show.
You'll also hear from several of my colleagues. We'll be sharing hosting and interview duties.
For our debut episode, I talked to Catherine Styler, who is Creative Commons' CEO.
Catherine started at CC in 2020, after many years as a member of
the European Parliament for Scotland, and then more recently as the CEO of the Open Knowledge
Foundation. It seemed like a good place to start for this podcast, hearing from CC's new leader
about her career and her vision for what's next for the Creative Commons movement.
